natural problem: Machiavelli added together $1+3i$ and $2-4i$. What number did he get?
natural solution: Adding together the real part and imaginary parts separately, we have $(1+2)+(3-4)i=\boxed{3-i}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: complex
assumes h0 : "a = Complex (Re 1) (Im 3)"
and h1 : "b = Complex (Re 2) (Im (-4))"
shows  "a + b = Complex (Re 3) (Im (-1))"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Machiavelli added together $1+3i$ and $2-4i$. What number did he get? The final Answer is 3-i
 ### Proof
 Adding together the real part and imaginary parts separately, we have $(1+2)+(3-4)i=\boxed{3-i}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: complex
assumes h0 : "a = Complex (Re 1) (Im 3)"
and h1 : "b = Complex (Re 2) (Im (-4))"
shows  "a + b = Complex (Re 3) (Im (-1))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of the complex numbers $1 + 3i$ and $2 - 4i$. The final answer is $3 - i$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "a = Complex (Re 1) (Im 3)"
and h1 : "b = Complex (Re 2) (Im (-4))"
and h2 : "c = a + b"
shows  "c = Complex (Re 3) (Im (-1))"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Machiavelli added together $1+3i$ and $2-4i$. What number did he get? The final Answer is 3-i
 ### Proof
 Adding together the real part and imaginary parts separately, we have $(1+2)+(3-4)i=\boxed{3-i}$.
 *)

fixes a b c :: complex
assumes h0 : "a = Complex (Re 1) (Im 3)"
and h1 : "b = Complex (Re 2) (Im (-4))"
and h2 : "c = a + b"
shows  "c = Complex (Re 3) (Im (-1))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Add the complex numbers $(1 + 3i)$ and $(2 - 4i)$. The final answer is $(3 - i)$.
